replies.context: Not sure what the tank is made of, but the outer wrap is carbon fiber. Very strong.

altitude is irrelevant. the tank accelerated at 9.8m/s/s (acceleration due to gravity) until it reached max velocity as determined by its aerodynamic shape (around 200 mph I would guess). The threat to its existence would be heat of re-entry, not altitude. I can only speculate that the stainless steel outer skin of the rocket protected the carbon fiber tank from burning up.

Thanks for setting me straight. I have been under the asinine impression that falling from space / re-entry heat equaled high altitude.
Appreciate your wisdom.

It's curious that given the fact that if an object re-entering our atmosphere doesn't hit exactly the right vector, it will either generate enough heat to turn into a cinder, or just bounce off into space.

my guess it that your estimate of 200 mph is a bit high.

there is a lot of surface area and very little weight.  
therefore the drag would be substantial compared to the force of gravity.
while not quite a balloon full of air (much less Helium) ...

still wouldn't want to be hit by it.

context:
I wonder if the homeowner could have kept them from retrieving the tank?
Could he legally have claimed ownership?
Could he have legally prevented them from coming onto his property?
Any attorneys out there with some answers?
Just curious.

replies.context: If an airliner crashed on his land, could he have legally kept the government from coming onto his property?  I think not!
If Space X is considered government, probably not. They always seem to get things back.

(1) The tank never becomes his.
(2) If he grants property access, the owners of the tank must recover it entirely at their expense according to a schedule agreeable and reasonable to the landowner.
(3) He can stop them from entering the property unless the government decides it is in the national interest, national security, hazard, etc. Then the government is responsible for removing the tank and repairing the property.
(4) If he prevents property access, he must return the tank to a place they designate at his expense.
(5) If he doesn't return the tank, he can be charged with illegal possession of property and be civilly sued for the value of the tank.
(6) Without legal action, he can ask that any damage to the property be repaired and the owners of the tank are obliged to do so, once the tank is returned.
If SpaceX had abandoned the second stage to burn in its de-orbit, they might no longer have ownership claim.
Yeah...no. Under international law, things can't be "abandoned" in space. You always own it, whether it burns up or not.
I see your point, especially if that debris caused damage. Someone would be responsible financially.
If a slug from your weapon lands on a neighbors property that is considered trespassing. I'm not a lawyer but I watched Law and Order on TV until it got too woke.
Why would he?
In Texas, Yes!
Bring a warrant.  No?  Shoot on sight.
Who would want a damaged tank? It would just be junk to the average person. Seems a better idea to return it so that it can be studied.
On Ebay, you can sell anything. There are people there who would buy packages of water that were labeled 'ice seeds'.
If the Tank had HIT the home , would it still have been PROPERTY of Space X , and Space X Liable for the Damages and Mental Stress ? Might have been a better question .

context: The real question is why Elon Musk and Space-x are allowed to pollute the entire worlds near space orbits with his planned mission of putting up thousands of these things

replies.context: The cube satellites he is putting up are not polluting near earth orbit and they are very small, self steering, possess automated collision avoidance systems and are being deployed in an agreement with NASA that they will maneuver away from any other satellite.  They are part of a global wireless broadband system and since nobody owns Space, Musk is as entitled to its use as any other company and there are many that have satellites in orbit besides governments.
The same reason plutocrats have been allowed to pollute the planet since the Industrial Revolution - money.
I'm pretty sure they were allowed to do that before the Industrial Revolution as well - they just might not have been as efficient at it.

Don‚Äôt see how a small cube satellite that is designed to burn up in the atmosphere when it exhausts its usefulness can be considered pollution.  The real pollution is the tons of useless non functioning satellites in high orbits and in geosynchronous orbit that were not designed to self immolate when their lifespan expired.  Someone like Elon Musk will actually make another fortune in the not too distant future taking contracts from governments to retrieve their garbage from the limited space available in geosynchronous orbit so room can be made for newer generation satellites.

I agree with much of what you say - although the growing number of active satellites - not just Musk's but others - seem like they would pose some hazard to any person/machine venturing into space. They are already interfering with land-based astronomy so are 'pollution' in that sense. Per your comment, the ELSA-d  satellite (made by Astroscale) that launched a few days ago is a first step toward junk removal. Musk could never have gotten to where he is today had he spent much time obsessing over all the things that 'could' go wrong (and he does seem to be taking responsibility for controlled de-orbiting of things like second stage boosters - the 'controlled' part failed in this one case).

Undoubtedly there are ways to minimize risk and if I lived in an area without land-based broadband I'd definitely be interested in signing up for Starlink.
It's because we don't live under a communist regime.  If we did, we'd leave this to government.

replies.context: Because it's a rocket part versus an airplane part, everyone gets paranoid about the hazards of rockets.  Go figure.
Especially since it was subjected to about 3700 degrees of sterilization on it‚Äôs way back to earth.
Sterilization? 3700* dose not detoxify Hydrazine or any other fuels that would be on the rocket.
That might be an issue except Space X uses methane not Hydrazine.

Actually, Space X uses Methane (Metholox) in the Raptors, which are exploding in Texas. The Merlins use Kerosene (Kerolox). All satellites use Hydrazine, since it does not boil off and can be stored for years.

When the first stages land , either at the landing zones or on the barges, the men that safe the rockets are required to wear hazmat suits. The same was with the shuttles. These birds are covered with toxic residues.
The odds of winning the powerball twice in a row are much higher than that happening but if it did I am sure Space X is carrying a significant liability insurance policy.
